reviewText:
Kate Winslet and Leonardo DiCaprio costar in "Revolutionary Road" as April and Frank Wheeler, a typical suburban couple living a typical domestic life in 1955 suburbia. To outsiders, it appears that the Wheelers have it all: a lovely house, two beautiful children, a steady income, etc. The truth of the matter is, both April and Frank are absolutely miserable. Frank is stuck in the same stupid job his father had before him, and he doesn't think April appreciates all his hard work, which causes him to seek comfort outside his marriage in the arms of one of his floozy secretaries. Meanwhile, April is bored out of her mind with being a mother and a housewife. Desperate for a change of pace, she proposes to Frank that they pack up their kids and move to Paris in order to turn their boring lives into an adventure. At first Frank is all for the idea, until he's offered a big promotion at work. Unfortunately, the change of plans doesn't sit well with April, and the Wheelers soon find their lives headed on a downward spiral of self-destruction,

"Revolutionary Road" is based on the novel by Richard Yates, and it is an extremely good adaptation of the book. Winslet and DiCaprio both deliver the best performances of their careers so far, definitely deserving of Oscar nominations. The film is incredibly depressing but brilliantly well-done. It illustrates the importance of following your dreams before it's too late. (Also, in my opinion, it's a wonderful pro-choice film...you will see why during the last 15 minutes.) This is definitely one of the best films I've seen in a long time, and I highly recommend it.

A lot of people who see this film will probably think of that line from "Walden" by Thoreau: "The mass of people lead lives of quiet desperation."  Although that line is fitting for his film, I think there was more to it than just that.  To tell you the truth, I think the main character was April Wheeler.  She reminded me of Nora in "A Doll's House" by Ibsen: she was fiercely independent and trapped within the confines of society during the '50s.  I think one of the reasons she was attracted to her future husband, Frank, was because of his feelings of independence and not being afraid to live life to its fullest.  But then things happen and people change.  April gets pregnant and suddenly finds herself as a Susie-homemaker somewhere out in the suburbs of Connecticut.  One moment she has dreams of becoming the next Katharine Hepburn on Broadway, and the next moment she is hosting a tea party for the ladies' auxiliary club in her living room.  She is not happy with her life.  Frank, on the other hand, is doing well in his life: he's got a wife and kids, a recent promotion that pays a bundle, and some "afternoon delight" on the side.  He's not as anxious or unhappy with his life.  So what do we have here?  Someone who keeps dwelling on the past (April) and someone who is looking towards the future (Frank).  It's no wonder the Wheelers are constantly at each other's throats.  What I liked about this film was its acute observation of a marriage.  How some people in a marriage learn to grow up, accept responsibility, and get on with their lives.  And how other people are fiercely independent, were never meant to get married, and never learn to get on with their lives.  I realize our society dictates that as humans, we should study hard, go to college, find a job, and get married and have kids.  But who's to say that is meant for everybody?  It may have been all right for Frank, but certainly not April.  "Revolutionary Road" questions the whole structure of our society and that is what I found so brilliant about it.  It was unafraid to explore these issues.

If you ever think life can't get any worse, leave it to the movies to introduce you to characters whose despondent situations far surpass your own. Such characters thrive in Revolutionary Road, a film whose outlook reaches so far into a realm of stifling depression that the result is exhaustion. If only we could care for these people in some way, if only we could sympathize or connect, then their suffering might not have been wasted on uncaring eyes. If only.

For April (Kate Winslet) and Frank (Leonardo DiCaprio) it's love at first sight, and shortly after the seemingly inescapable rut of repetition. Frank assumes the dreary day job as a businessman sleepwalking through mindless work days, womanizing the new secretaries, and purposely slacking in his duties. April is the stay-at-home mother, trapped by her responsibilities and the sinking feeling that her life isn't being lived to the fullest. As the couple plots a course to a new life in the utopian Paris, harsh realities replace desperate dreams and difficult choices steadily destroy their chances at breaking free from the sordid existence they've created.

There really isn't anything to like about Revolutionary Road. The characters are all depressing, dysfunctional and annoying - but most of all they're presented in such a way that sympathy is practically out of the question. As April spirals into insanity and Frank broils out of control, the only sensibility comes from the clinically loony John (Michael Shannon) who is so obnoxious that even his explanation of their situation is troubling. The two children, who might also be used to muster sympathy, are frequently away, further disconnecting audiences from the crumbling leads. It's as if we are supposed to despise everyone in the film, responding with nothing but negativity toward their failures and shortcomings.

The dialogue is lacking as well, making Leonardo and Kate look as amateurish as their turns in Titanic. Some may argue that they're accomplished actors in their primes and that their performances are worthy of distinction - but even the climax of the film is laughable, along with nearly every sequence in which they bicker and yell. And their arguing takes up the majority of the runtime, making this incredibly dialogue-heavy melodramatic mess all lemons and no sugar. At several points Revolutionary Road is so ridiculously funereal it's funny. It's a movie that will make audiences reevaluate the worst performances and films of the year. Maybe it will also cheer up those viewers who can give thanks that their lives are not this socially impaired - or hit too close to home for others.

- The Massie Twins

It begins so innocently: A young man and a young woman glace at each other and immediately want to close the distance between them and get better acquainted. Such a moment can be found in James Cameron's "Titanic" early in the film, when the characters played by Leonardo DiCaprio and Kate Winslet first notice each other despite being separated by deck levels and social status. A very similar moment can be found at the beginning of Sam Mendes' "Revolutionary Road," and interestingly, it features the same two actors. Their characters see each other for the first time at a local party, and they're separated more by life goals than by stature. As wonderful as "Titanic" is, it's an escapist entertainment, a sweeping, epic romantic fantasy. "Revolutionary Road" is smaller, subtler, and painfully real. We know this because the youthful, nave love the characters share at the start disappears by the next scene, at which point they're already married and having a terrible fight.

Based on Richard Yates' novel, "Revolutionary Road" is a brilliant, unflinchingly honest examination of suburban life in 1950s America, where the outward appearance of domestic happiness meant everything to the average married couple. It tells the story of a corporate employee named Frank Wheeler (DiCaprio) and his stay-at-home wife, April (Winslet), who live in a picturesque but boring Connecticut neighborhood. Despite the fact that Frank hates his job, he's content to stick with it, knowing that he's expected to provide for his family. This isn't to say that he doesn't let himself go from time to time. Early in the film, he has an affair with a young secretary. The fascinating thing is that both of them seem so casual about what they're doing; if they regret their actions, they certainly don't show it. There isn't even a spark of emotion as he leaves her in a motel bed, asserting that she was swell.

April, on the other hand, yearns for something more out of life than just living in a suburb and raising her two children. Years ago, she was an aspiring actress. Now, she's in a domestic trap as a wife and mother. On the night of Frank's thirtieth birthday, she makes a radical suggestion: They should all move to Paris in the fall. Once there, she will get a secretarial job while Frank will be allowed to figure out what he actually wants to do with his life. It takes a little convincing, but Frank agrees, and for a time, his relationship with April improves. But it isn't long before life starts getting in the way. For one thing, absolutely no one takes their plan seriously, especially their neighbors, Shep (David Harbour) and Milly Campbell (Kathryn Hahn), who seem genuinely hurt by their wanting to leave. But truth be told, there is something a little phony about the glow that surrounds Frank and April, as if the idea is more appealing than actually moving.

There's more holding them back, of course, but I won't say what. I will, however, take the time to describe a subplot featuring another "Titanic" alumnus, Kathy Bates. She plays Helen Givings, the realtor who sold the Wheelers their house on Revolutionary Road. Even though she doesn't have much screen time, it's surprising just how much we learn about her. On the outside, she's polite and upbeat, with a pleasant face and charming smile. On the inside, she's judgmental and, in some ways, just as desperate as April. Her son, John (Michael Shannon), has just been released from a mental hospital, and as part of his rehabilitation, he begins spending time with the Wheelers. In the same way the blind Tiresias is able to see the truth about King Oedipus, John is the only character in "Revolutionary Road" with a firm grasp on Frank and April. But as insightful as he is, there does come a point when the truth really hurts.

What I really loved about this movie was the meticulous attention to dialogue. Every line in this movie felt natural, going not for obvious dramatic statements but for realistic outbursts of anger, hurt, and frustration. Even the quieter moments have an intensity all their own, as when Frank sits with the secretary at a restaurant; in that pivotal scene, he expresses--probably for the first time--the disappointment he feels for turning out exactly like his father. At the same time, there's an air of epiphany in his voice, as if he realized right then and there that he was never meant to be anything more than an office worker. Writer Justin Haythe evokes powerful emotions in his screenplay, and he does so without being condescending or clich.

Of course, well-written screenplays are only half the battle--you need talented actors to make the dialogue work. DiCaprio and Winslet have such believable onscreen chemistry, especially as their characters descend into a seemingly never-ending cycle of shouting matches. They fight so well, as if they were an actual married couple. After having eleven years to mature as performers, they may in fact be better than they were in "Titanic." One wonders what would have happened had the ship made it to America and Jack and Rose had gotten off together. Would the fairy-tale romance eventually end? Would they grow up to be as unfulfilled as Frank and April Wheeler? "Revolutionary Road" is such an amazing film, superbly cast, expertly plotted, and emotionally compelling, a sobering reminder that what we want doesn't always coincide with what we get. Even the crme de la crme of 2008--like "Changeling," "Gran Torino," and "Frost/Nixon"--are not as good as this film is.

I'm a very picky person when it comes to movies these days but this is worthy of a 5 star rating. It relates to the eye opening harsh reality we live in. It unveils the societal pressure we give in to work a 9-5 job all for the sake of money instead of being fearless and chasing our dreams. Instead of choosing, love, passion, adventure and new beginnings we choose status, big houses, meaningless objects, and repetition because we believe those things will make us happy. We believe the opinions of others are held at a higher value then the opinion we have of ourselves. Instead of actually being a better person we give an illusion we are better with fake smiles and a perfectly curated lifestyle. I'm so pleased someone could translate to film in to what I think in my head on a regular basis. Even though it made me ball my eyes out, I truly appreciate the honesty, sublime acting, beautiful cinematography and how truly inspired I feel.
Depressing movie. The acting, score, and cinematography were beautiful. The only redeeming value about the story, however, is that it made me grateful to be single.
If you are looking for something sweet and uplifting, this is not it....

I really enjoy DiCaprio and Winslet, but this movie is a real downer.  Man supports wife and kids.  Wife is at home caring for her children and lovely house-yet she wants more-and chooses not to be happy and turns against her husband because he is content with their life and she is bored.  It does not get better-the ending is so, so sad.  Blah.
I personally did NOT care for this movie... I can love both of these actors in movies but this movie [the story line] was completely disheartening and depressing to me.

Two hours of my life I will never get back.  Can't believe DiCaprio and Winslet needed the money so bad they took on this  turd.  Only thing good  is it is leaving Prime on March 1, so no one else will subjected to the torture.

This movie is about truth. The acting - writing - cinematography - everything was excellent. Most people live lives of quiet desperation. Most people don't pursue their dreams, enjoy their work, or lives life with passion. They jump on the hamster wheel in pursuit or the "American dream" and material gratification. Denial and alcohol will keep them going and FB "likes" on their posts and happy looking pictures helps keep the illusion alive.
well done married life angst in suburbs in the 50's that could just as easily translate to today. Moments of happiness.
"No one forgets the truth; they just get better at lying." Makes you wonder which road you're choosing...comfort or courage?

It is truly a thought-provoking movie - add to this the above average acting of Kate Winslet and Leonardo, you get the perfect movie.

After watching this movie - my wife asked me not to show movies like this again - it is really depressing so be ready for it.  I would watch it all over again, it is really a true reflection of the reality of our dreams, aspirations.  The escapism by trying to find pleasure in things ... the desire to do something radical hoping that it will change things ...

Overall a beautiful, thought-provoking and depressing movie.
Fantastic gripping story. Kept me on the edge of my seat. Didn't fall in love with either of the main characters which made it hard for me to cry yet still a moving story and the best acting!

This film got better as life goes on. I first saw it as a 20 year old with my whole life ahead of me, I found it hard to understand why Winslet's character made the choices she did...eight years on I still don't completely identify but am sympathetic, to both of the main characters. We live in a different time (let's not harp about going back to the golden 50s) but many of the issues are still valid to people today. Worth a watch but not "entertainment" in the "away from thinking" sense.
Very good film, although some parts were very sad. I think alot of married couples probably go through these same times of struggles and problems, no matter what era. The acting was also superb!

This movie wakes up the part of your brain that asks: Why Go On?  Conformist 1950s, though stylin' in design, clothes, what a loathsome time to be alive if you wanted more from life than keeping in lockstep with the Jones'.  I was only able to watch this while doing some mindless work at the same time, this is not a movie to watch if you want to relax or forget your woes.
I like to watch it again and again to know and think about each of characters more and more

Acting is at it's best by the entire cast ... delivered with intensity that you seek to find in a move.  However, the story is so overwhelmingly depressing that I cannot recommend it ... unless you are looking to feel numbing sadness.

Really liked this and related to Winslet's character a lot. It felt like a dramatization of "The Feminine Mystique" which was basically about middle class women in this time period who were not allowed to work and more or less went insane from boredom. All alone in a big house in a big empty neighborhood, washing dishes and folding laundry all day long. Ugh. Really impressive look into the push and pull of married life, thwarted expectations, the burden of childbirth and hard gender roles, the dynamics between married couples, etc etc. And for all the people who thought that it was boring and slow, well that's kind of the point. Car crashes and chase scenes would betray this movie's dedication to its source material. "Boring and slow" is part of the characters' problem. Loved it.

I've never written a review for a film in my life.  This is the first.  I only have this to say.  The writing for this film ranks up there with Death of a Salesman.  Incredible and insightful and brutally real.  If you have ever been married or divorced or in a family with real emotion, this film will strike a chord.  Like it or not it's an insightful glimpse of the extraordinary discomfort that comes with true feelings expressed or otherwise in an honest relationship.  Not that honesty is always the policy, but honesty to the fibre of one's own being.  This is the beauty of Revolutionary Road and the beauty of Death of a Salesman.  Bravo.

SPOILER ALERT*Profane, blasphemous, slow. Great actors wasted on a confusing plot. The action picks up when April (KateWinslet) convinces her hubby Frank (Leo DiCaprio) that they should pack up their idyllic New England existence and move to Paris. She plays a wanna be actress, never gets her big break and presumably marries Leo ( Frank) and gets trapped in the suburbs. First they're excited about moving despite pushback from their friends. But, suddenly, anger and despondency take over the movie. Too many flashbacks explain the supposed deterioration of the marriage which appears to result from Aprils inability to communicate (which explains why she never made it as an actress). Every time Frank tries to talk to her about her feelings, she shuts him down and insults him so its no wonder she feels suffocated! Their kids disappear halfway through the movie for no apparent reason. Frank unexpectedly gets his big break at his humdrum Manhattan company, effectively shutting down any plans of moving to Paris. Multiple screaming matches basically make up the bulk of the last hour. April decides to abort her 3rd child and commit suicide at the same time to escape her terribly comfortable life. I guess this film is supposed to double as a cautionary tale/womens rights, but fails on both counts. In some ways it mirrored Whos Afraid of Virginia Woolf? but won't become a classic. Oh well, it was nice to see Jack and Rose together again.

If you can afford to stream movies in the comfort of your own home ...but yet still feel trapped in that home, this movie will really speak to you.  I think the haunting piano score is the the best part about the film because it spoke to me something internal.. about oh yeah, that's right this life is only one way and I'm running out of time.. whatever happened to my goals and dreams..?.  Yes, this is a movie about first world problems.. full of beautiful suburbia, big homes, green lawns, good looking rich, white folk with 2 perfect kids.  Yet the couple is miserable.  They have it all.  Yet, its not enough.  He is doing the same stupid job his father did.  She flamed out on pursuing being famous.. and has a bad case of Margaret Mead's "problem with no name."  Its bleak and too familiar.  We don't have to worry about clean water, I mean unless you're in Michigan.. so this is what a great number of us deal with.. that crushing unhappiness and subtle reminder that this is your last chance.. no one gets out of here alive.  Will you envy the dancers or go dancing yourself?  Just 3 days ago I was fired from a job working for a jerk I hated.. (it was his mistake, sorry but I was the good guy here and people are still upset I got rail roaded)... anyhow, that jerk and watching this movie reminded me of some goals I haven't yet achieved.. .to live and thrive as a single man in NYC while I still can.. before I get too old and it all slips away.. cue the piano....
Slow, boring
awful movie, very depressing

Skillfully superb acting and an excellently crafted screenplay create a thoughtful, albeit, brutally honest  look  at relationships, social mores and societal roles in pre-1960's upper middle class  America.  If you're looking for things being blown up,  speeding cars in fiery crashes or any kind of special effect movie wizardry, this is not your movie. But if you would like to contemplate how well we actually know the partners we spend our lives with, consider what truly brings and keeps us together, witness the immense differences that have occurred in American society over the last six decades as well as the fundamental truths about being human that are never changing, this is the movie for you. It is an absolute gem.

I truly love this movie. It's a passionate, fantastically acted period drama set in the 1950s. DiCaprio and Winslet both give wonderful performances as a young married couple who, at the beginning of their relationship, believed they were special and destined for great things, only to find themselves later stuck in the sort of "keeping up with the Joneses"-looking suburban life they loathe. Winslet's character is constantly asking who made the rules to the life they are living and, better yet, why do they have to follow them? She suggests they move to Paris, a place DiCaprio once told her he felt the most alive and one she's never been to. For a moment, they look set to escape their dull existence, before DiCaprio gets a promotion at the job he hates, forcing his retreat into the world he swore was sucking out his soul. Winslet feels betrayed and more like a prisoner than ever before. The story is a heartbreaker and especially relatable to anyone who has ever experienced the descent from young conqueror to the conquered.
big fan of both, loved it.

The main redeeming value of the film was the powerful acting of the characters, particularly Leonardo DiCaprio who was thoroughly convincing. The supposed theme of the movie, however, the desperation of dull, middle class life in suburbia, seemed to hover over the screenplay like an empty shibboleth, artificially imposed upon a story that never really developed it into anything believable. The sudden change in Kate Winslet's character late in the movie was also not believable, though it's difficult to say if that was due to Winslet's acting or an ineffectual screenplay, which also lacked plot and character development in the beginning of the film. Ultimately, the finished product seemed more like a rough first draft that  still required a lot more refinement.
Great Movie. Lots of Emotion. Cool to see Kate and Leonardo together again!

I saw this years ago and found it very moving, a drama that almost borders on a psychological thriller. Not quite, but close. Its definitely more than just a drama.

For those who reviewed this and chalked it up as boring or depressing, they probably don't much care for psychological thriller-type movies. The plot takes a couple of twists, and it almost hurts to see how much angst the characters inflict on each other.

This is not just a drama about a couple experiencing the malaise if middle age, in a middle class neighborhood, in mid-century America. It goes way beyond that. Its hard to take simply because its a grim reminder that we often treat our own loved ones worse than anyone. This is not a good choice if you're hoping for a story that wraps everything up in a neat box with a neatly tied bow, with everyone living happily ever after.

If you liked American Beauty, youll probably like this too.

Both Winslet and DiCaprio put in very solid performances. Theyre completely immersed in their roles here.
pointless dead end

Absolutely dreadful. Depressing awful movie with supposedly great actors. No redeeming quality. Undeveloped character, sad dialogue, full of 60's stereotype. Wish I could take the two hours back I wasted.
Excellent story line and acting.  Makes you think.
A terrible, depressing, and uninspiring story. Probably the worst film I have ever seen. Wish that I could somehow get the two hours of my life that I just wasted back.
Excellent actors. Very believable. Yes, the story is sad but it makes you think about your own goals in live.
DEPRESSING

I thought the storyline were good, and the acting better. It tells a story of love and loss, and for many couples out there who are going through difficult decisions, I can really see this movie speaking to them.

The slowest, zero plot, zero acting movie in ages!  I cannot believe these actors reduced themselves to making this movie.  After staying with it with hopes for improvement for an hour, I still could not fast fwd to any spot to peak any interest.  The end was ridiculous.

Great period piece.  I enjoyed it and watched the darker moments with understanding and gratitude that it's just a movie!  The art is what's sculpted by the opposing forces at play:  ambition, playfulness, lack of adventure, desire for adventure, desire for security, friendships, co-worker relationships, roles filled out by the lives of ordinary people every day.
Worst movie I've ever seen. And I've seen both Napoleon Dynamite, and Two Girls One Cup. Do not watch
Great to see them together again but largely dull & pointless.

I hated that God's name was taken in vain! I did not see the movie after those horrible words appeared I stopped seeing it. I believe your movies should be rated such as general or X or something like that.
SO SAD THAT IS HOW ONE LIVED IN THAT TIME ERA
Not good at all. Really really depressing all the way through

Well...this is one movie we can add to the list of "real talk".  Just imagine how unhappy women were during those days.  Unfortunately, some women are living to pleeeeeezzzz everyone else and not themselves, at least, every once and awhile. She just couldn't t take it anymore....not sure what words can explain the emotions for "when you're done you're done".  I can imagine that many people have a different opinion and many people don't agree on this story and each person's own "challenges".  We can say it's only a movie or "is it". Just saying... PS for the women of today with the mouth of a man and just don't give a sh--,  who knows what is right anymore? which group of women are truly happy? The demure/wifey or the Damn you and if you don't like it kiss my A-- women?? which one is more happier....Will we ever know the truth?
Terrible movie. I can't believe I watched til the end. I literally threw my hands up.

Terrible movie
boring ...
basic premise. If you don't do everything in your power to fulfill your whimsical dreams from your youth, regardless of you will hurt, you can never be happy.

The acting was very good; not great, but very good, but I don't blame the actors. They could only do so much with that awful script. The real issue was the writing. Why celebrate a total abject failure? Aren't there enough of those in all of our lives without adding this artificial one? Don't we see enough heartache and disappointment without some bozo pretending it's art? It's the easiest thing in the world to find angst and despair in the world where we live? It's everywhere. These are the times that try men's souls. These are the times when their hearts shall fail them. A true literary or cinematic triumph depicts a human victory, a magical moment when the human spirit overcomes the emptiness and chaos. Shouldn't we come away from novels and movies feeling uplifted and encouraged? Is an artist worth our attention if all he or she does is disappoint us? Isn't that the easiest thing in the world to do? Isn't it a poor substitute for genius? No thanks. I wish someone had warned me.
It was dope
dark, really dark.
Waste of time
Great actors, awful script. Basically two people unhappy and selfish in a marriage. Very disturbing ending that makes you feel sick to your stomach. Just all around awful

5 Stars for the story, acting and message. It's a very well made movie! Hell of depressing and I can't say I loved it because it's disturbing, dysfunctional and tough.
However, I agree with most reviews I read on here. If you want to feel good, don't watch it. It delivers a great message about not taking your partner for granted or life and staying true to oneself and live live with courage, love and understanding.
Which is what I wish they would have done in their marriage, In this case it was like a piece of art, you look at it and you'll definitely feel something, maybe start questioning your life or your relationship. I am sure glad my life is good!

Terribly sad movie, but the acting was fine- especially by Winslet.  The movie is thought-provoking though and that isn't a bad thing.  I would assume that most people won't like the movie, but many will appreciate it.
Well its kind of disturbing at some extent but the movie has done great in potraying a couple's conflicting life. Great acting by Leonardo and Kate..

Everything about this movie was real and revolutionary. From it's script to director to producer and actors, they all encapsulated the reality of who we want to be and the person we become after we enter adulthood. Troubleshooting through life we often digress from the path we should have taken to fulfill our hopes, capabilities and dreams. Sure it may be tough and loaded with challenges, but then, what isn't?!
In the movie, Revolutionary Road, they dare to think out loud of what happened to those hopes and dreams that brought the couple together. They play it safe for the sake the family but then, the same thing is tearing them apart.

The question is how long can a group of people play truth OR dare? Is it possible to be truthful and daring enough to be our best?
I found the acting to be incredible, as Kate Winslet and Leonardo DiCaprio have an amazing on-screen chemistry. However, this is no "feel good" film, as the plot line is realistically depressing.
Very dramatic and interesting movie. Thought it was sad & dark, but very real and relatable

Acting was interesting but the plot wasn't what you typically see during this era. Guess they were highlighting 'mental illness' or 'living the life most people dream of'. I don't understand why you need another individual if you dream of a different life. Sad and Depressing
I dislike any kind of violence including verbal violence! I Really did not like this movie though it had some great actors, there were no good parts

That was incredible. The acting was some of the best I have ever seen in my life. That movie is amazing. I felt like I was there experiencing it first hand observing them as their story was happening. I was in suspense of what Kate Winslet was going to say or do most of the time. She absolutely killed it. So did Leo and M. Shannon. I'm like a changed being after viewing that. Wow. Wow. Art at its finest. Thank you all involved. I am blown away, and have a new favorite movie. I feel like I should shower, weird.
I love the actors, but this movie was a disappointment. Honestly a bad and boring movie. It moved to slow and it was too depressing.

Terribly thought provoking...and too true...but not for all. Escaping into the great roles played is easy, given the quality of acting, but it's too important to recognize they do not represent all families...at least those who grow together...who convey their true character, blemishes and all, who trust...not because it is earned, but because it is promised in the vows of marriage.  Growing together is the key...too few, and this couple, so easily lose along the way....
Great actors, lousy movie.
Gripping to the core!
Terrible. Awkward. Lots of intense arguing that made kate look like she was psychotic. Just weird

Don't waste your time watching it. I tried to keep watching the movie until it just got worse as it went.

Take for instance, a review from a Doctor

"BUNCH OF NONSENSE.
why? I'm a doc who is old enough to remember the "good old days".

One: it's very hard if not impossible to put the tube into the cervix by oneself unless you are a contortionist.
also, You have to dilate the cervix first, which hurts.

Two: the catheter was inserted by the local abortionist, not by the woman.

Three: The "self administered" abortion was a knitting needle: Usually this was only done by the poorest and most ignorent patients we treated: and when they came in with a perforated uterus, we had to do an emergency hysterectomy.

Four: back in the fifties, every upper class lady, and a lot of the lower class ones, knew the local abortionist, and rarely had complications. The one at our "college" lived in the next town and was a full MD.

Five: deaths became rare after penicillin and blood transfusions were invented.

The only one I know about was from a dirty catheter, with retained fetus and placenta that got infected (i.e. second trimester).

Conclusion:
Propaganda of course, to scare the PC into hating pro life people."

This is obviously a well done movie that is true to the tone of the book; which itself was a product of the author's own unstable childhood.  This is an "art imitates life" story. From my reading it is emblematic of the "age of anxiety" literature of the 50s and 60s.  This movie has value in that it demonstrates "lives of quiet desperation" as they are lived in suburbs all over the world; and it tackles difficult social issues such as materialism, abortion and the right to one's own body, gender economic and social divides, marriage and children, ideas about definitions of happiness, etc.

I do have a problem with the story as told.  In the first few minutes, the plot coyly promises an uplifting story about marriage and family, only to lead us into a narrow view of miscommunication, anger, disappointment, depression and desperation.  Having reminded us of the worst parts of ourselves, of the hopelessness that can be life,  the movie ends without taking the time and care to give us hope that the best sides of us can prevail.

Even their first glances felt uncomfortable but weren't supposed to be. This movie really drags and is a drag. The 2 stars are for the sets. The other actors were mostly okay.

A fundamental existential question of our lives has been the goal or purpose of it. If there is a purpose, then how should we live, such that our lives fulfil that purpose? Philosophers as well as ordinary men have pondered this question for millenniums. Seventy years ago, Jean-Paul Sartre declared that there is no meaning or purpose to our lives other than what our own freedom defines. This meant that there is no joy in looking up to a God or a Guru to give us meaning to our lives. We must rely on our own resources to find an answer and craft our future. But the future is not knowable. It is inherently uncertain. This causes  anxiety and despair from which there is no escape. The larger the purpose, the higher is our responsibility and hence higher the anxiety and despair. This film explores this existential dilemma through a young American couple in their late twenties during the 1950s in suburban Connecticut. The moment I saw that Sam Mendes is the director of the film, I was confident that the subject will be handled with great skill. His treatment of suburban American life  in American Beauty gave me that faith. The film itself is based on Richard Yates classic novel of the same title, written in the 1960s.

The film is set in the mid-1950s and gets off to a flying start, with April and Frank, two young people, meeting at a party and getting interested in each other. In the next frame, we see them already married with a couple of children and living in a lovely suburban corner house in Connecticut with beautifully tended lawns and well-appointed interior decorations. Frank Wheeler works for a firm in NY selling business machines. April is a housewife now, but was an aspiring actor prior to her marriage. A few years into their marriage, as Frank is on his thirtieth birthday, April realizes that they are just living a humdrum existence. It is not the dream life they envisaged when getting married. Instead, they are just following the template given to them by the post-war American society - that of getting a home on debt, consuming on debt, having boring get-togethers with boring neighbours, working a job that he hates and repeating the whole charade year after year. Little does she recognize that neither of them actually has any real, passionate dreams to pursue but only have fantasies about such a dream.
April finds that Frank loved Paris city when he spent some time there years before. So, she suggests that they leave Connecticut and go live in Paris, where she will work as a translator in the US  embassy while Frank can discover what he would love to do with his life. April believes that Paris would give meaning to their lives and show them what their dreams are. Frank agrees and they announce their decision to the total disbelief of his colleagues at work and their neighbours. Just as they are making preparations to leave, April finds that she is pregnant again and Frank is offered a promotion and significantly more money at work. Doubts set in and plans are derailed amidst bitter acrimony. Ostensibly, the rethink is because you cant support three children in Paris on a secretarys salary and that it is foolish to turn down a promotion with a lot more money in these difficult times! They update their friends on the changed plans. While entertaining their friend Helen and her family, April and Frank are brutally confronted by Helens son John, who is a Ph. D in Mathematics and also just out of a mental institution. With searing honesty, he shows them their delusions and exposes their postures and pretensions. The film moves on to a devastating climax.

The story is splendidly narrated and I simply loved the film. Leonardo di Caprio and Kate Winslet are brilliant as Frank and April in their search for a meaning to their lives and pursuit of happiness. Watching them hardly felt like they were acting. It was like taking a peep into our own  lives. The 1950s is brought to us graphically in the way we see a whole train load of men disembarking at the Grand Central station in New York city, clad in stylish suits and smart-looking hats. The cultural feel of the Eisenhower-era values is brought to us by the conversations April has with her neighbours and the ones Frank has with his colleagues at the office. Watching it in 2017, one notices immediately that everyone smokes incessantly and drinks quite substantially. Given the theme of the film, it is as if they use these stimulants to take their minds away from facing up to the emptiness of  a consumer society, selling false American Dreams of affluence.

The film has made me want to read other books by author Richard Yates, on whose book this film is based. Even though the book was written more than fifty years ago, it is amazing how relevant it is still today. After all, it asks us, Leave alone trying to understand the world or other people. Do you actually know who you are?

This is an excellent, thought provoking movie that examines the painful choices that people find themselves forced to make; the conflict between individual freedom and conformity; the compromises people make in a post-industrial society; reminiscent of "Mad Men," "One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest" or "Five Easy Pieces." But even further, Revolutionary Road also reminds us of the limitations with which women were forced to contend prior to the "Roe v. Wade" Supreme Court decision. Though set in the 1950's and 60's the questions it raises are pertinent to political discussions that are still happening today. Kate Winslet and Leonardo DiCaprio give passionate performances as the "ideal" suburban couple struggling to hold onto their marriage while trying to maintain their sanity and dignity in the face of powerful social forces intent on stomping them out.

All I could think of when this movie ended was - why in the world did Leonardo DiCaprio makes such a silly movie?

Nobody caught the meaning of this movie!!  Can't believe it.  The irony and the well kept secret ...almost to the end...was fantastic..  For all who missed it and all who will watch it...don't miss it:  she was mentally ill.  Her husband, who loved her, accepted that she was mentally ill and humored her.  A well hidden secret until the very end...his callousness and seeming 'play boy wannabe' demeanor was all about his 'wife' and living true to the promise of 'for better or for worse".  If you don't see it, watch it again, there are subtle but very real clues almost from the first minute throughout!!  Or, go to the library and ask for the "What the author meant" an old but effective tool to understand the true purpose of why we write what we write.

I just watched this movie and it was out standing. The acting was so real. The emotions were raw. I loved it. Outsiders thought the Wheelers were special and hypnotic. They were and the feeling was shared by both Frank and April. They had the American dream and the sky was the limit for these two and their children. The perfect family but April wanted more. Frank wanted to make April happy but her dream to run away, live in Paris and find themselves sounded fantastic but life got in the way and Frank couldn't leave security for an unknown future. Watching this movie was like being a fly on the wall, being privy into their complex marriage. The acting was so real and so believable. It was like they weren't acting at all. It was spellbinding! The era was portrayed exactly as it was then. Women just wanted to get married, have children and live the 1950's American dream. But, April wanted more. She said she was suffocating. She was unhappy and she looked desperately for a way out, another kind of life that held promise of excitement and uncertainty. She was bored. Being a mother was unfulfilling for her and her marriage was too safe. Poor Frank. He would have done anything for her but throwing away everything he had worked so hard for was not going to happen.. He thought for awhile he could share her fantasy, but in the end he couldn't do it. Most people thought Frank was in control but in all truth it was April. He tried so hard to fulfill her life but nothing he could do would ever satisfy her. April was a very unhappy woman but it was far more than that. She was mentally ill. She had all the characteristics of being by-polar. She was plagued with constant highs and lows and from the outside looked in she appeared very appealing but it was anything but. She was sexually hyper. Her hormones had a lot to do with that but it was also part of her illness. When she started dancing in the bar with her neighbor it was all premeditated on her part and the neighbor, always desiring her went right along with her game. I was mesmerized by her dance and her oozing sexuality. Throughout her marriage to Frank their sex life was thoroughly enjoyed by both of them but I suspect for her it was much more than that. It is a characteristic of bi-polar, extreme sexuality. She showed manic behavior and chronically depressed behavior throughout their marriage. Yes, she was bi-polar but she also had other mental disorders. She was not able to love. At the end of the movie she had a complete psychotic break. She was not able to distinguish reality from depressive psychosis. She was in desperate need of hospitalization to stabilize her deep depression, because all she could see was hopelessness. This was the 50's and this behavior was not easily recognizable in those years. I felt so sorry for Frank. They were both young, immature and prideful but he inherently was a good, stable man. He loved April with all his heart but she couldn't return the feelings because she had none for him or her children. The thought of her having another child made her suicidal. The botched abortion was her way of committing suicide. She didn't see a way out because of her depression. Death to her was a release from her tormenting life. That was the illness talking. She had so much to be grateful for and many reasons to be happy but because of her mental illness, what looks good to others is not shared or felt with her. After her break from reality when she begged Frank to stop talking and leave her alone, Frank was beside himself and in anger retaliated with harsh words that Alice couldn't feel. The next morning, Alice appeared to be over her tantrum and Frank was so happy and releaved. He asked her if she hated him and her response was of cause not. That was a true response from her because she had no feelings for him. They were all for herself and her deep depression. Frank was so releaved. He didn't want to see the truth and accept the fact that she was mentally ill. He didn't know how to deal with that, so he left for work, knowing deep inside things were precariously dangerous. Such a sad movie. The acting is so intensely wonderful. I highly recommend this movie!

Revolutionary Road is the story of a married couple who is dissatisfied living the "cookie cutter" life of the suburbs. After some time of being miserable, they come to the agreement that they do not have to live by society's standard. They find a solution to their unhappiness, but their perfect plan is soon interrupted by one of life's common happenings. This is where the couple splits- April, the wife, continuing to envision life outside the suburbs and her husband, Frank, accepting life as it is. April's yearning to escape and Frank's newfound peace drive them apart.
I enjoyed this movie, but I am not sure that I would purchase it. It isn't a movie that I want to re-watch over and over, but  it's unforgettable. It isn't a feel-good movie by any means, but I found myself connecting with both characters, April and Frank. This connection kept me interested to see what would happen next.

Directed by Sam Mendes and starring Leonardo DiCaprio and Kate Winslet, REVOLUTIONARY ROAD would like to be a scathing indictment of 1950s America and suburbia but unfortunately fails to say anything fresh, and its satirical edge is remarkably dull. Still, there were some fine performances and individual moments that stand out, not to mention the excellent filmmaking on display. The story is about the Wheelers, a couple who live in the Revolutionary Hill Estates, a Connecticut suburban community. On the outside their life looks idyllic, but underneath it all there is a deep dissatisfaction and resentment that begins to manifest itself. The banality of suburban life is not a new topic in literature or film, and this film does a good job getting the surface details right in order to make its point rather clear. However, I didn't feel like it did anything I haven't seen before in other films, like THE ICE STORM and Sam Mendes' own AMERICAN BEAUTY. In fact, this felt a lot like AMERICAN BEAUTY, with the exception that it was set in the 1950s. Even the score was reminiscent of the one for that previous film. However, that one had a more arty feel that this film didn't have. Still, despite the (ironically) banal subject matter, this film was well put together on every front, both technical and performance-wise. Leonardo DiCaprio and Kate Winslet do a good job playing their roles, although there isn't too much depth to their characters at all. There were a few smaller roles that had familiar faces behind them, but they also felt under-developed. By far the best performance in the entire film was a small role played by Michael Shannon, the temporarily institutionalized son of the couple who sold the house on Revolutionary Road to the Wheelers. His couple of scenes have that acerbic wit and bite to them that I wish had been more prevalent in the overall story, which felt downright sterile at times. From a technical standpoint, the film is flawless and the photography was beautiful, belying the ugliness of the atmosphere projected by its characters. Overall, I didn't hate this film but I didn't think it entirely justified its existence either. It does a good job of portraying suburban malaise, but at the end of it you have to ask "So what?" Still it made for a pleasant, if unspectacular, viewing experience and was capped off with the perfect ending.

This was a great movie because the subject matter is so unique.  I read a review of this movie years ago, describing the Suburbs to be the death of the soul.  How chilling, and yet, it is what everyone aspires to.  The third child, then the fourth until the wife looks like an old hag unless she goes out and gets botox so her face can look frozen like all the 40 something reality show women.  Yates does not address what draws people to that life.  He implies there is living up to your parents expectations and fitting in and conforming to what everyone else is doing and pursuing a life of materialism.  Keeping up with the Jones, or in today's world, the Kardashians.  Is it that parenting is just way more draining than most people ever thought about, there is the implication that no one is really prepared for the true nature of a adult life as we know it, especially since the 70s were known as the me decade, post birth control, where couples for the first time in history, could consider becoming fulfilled in an artistic, profoundly spiritual way.  April knows she wants to be an actress but the De caprio's character has no clue.  We know he owes it to himself to take some time and find out what that could be.  The insane son of their realtor neighbor is the little nagging voice in his head that tells him to go for his DREAMS and keep searching until he finds it, but he never does.  If you think about the way society has been since the 50s, it has only gotten more alienating, celebrating individual expression and uniqueness less and less.  April thinks she has the perfect answer which is Paris, but that too, could be just another delusion. She is so desperate to feel special, she sleeps with her best friend's husband.  He is so desperate to feel that he is a person he sleeps with a secretary who eyes him in an elevator.  Paris is a beautiful city but has the same issues as any other metropolis, competition, its very expensive, cold, exclusionary, celebrates the past and pedigrees.  When tourists go there and dream of finding the solution to all their problems and run away to a glamorous, romantic place where everything magically falls into place.  it would be interesting to know how many Americans move there from their middle class frumpy existence and then suddenly find themselves forty pounds thinner, much better off in every way simply because they move to the most decadent city in the world.  April is dreaming a silly fantasy and her husband knows it but he doesn't know how to do anything other than do a better job at suburbia.  The book is somewhat autobiographical, Yates did get a a divorce after having 2 kids, did live in Paris for some time, did search for artistic expression, did smoke nonstop and did feel modern life sucked the soul out of men in the 50s.

April is textbook Borderline Personality Disorder. The fact that she switches instantly from love to hate to a robotic lack of emotion and empathy, and in and out of alternate realities, indicates severe psychological dysfunction that had no contemporary terminology in the 1950s, so no wonder Frank was constantly dismayed by her irrational mood swings and multiple personalities.

Since the original book was written in the 1950s this film doesn't really fit in with all the other recent revisionist Hollywood films which are hellbent on portraying the 1950s Great American Dream as a hoax, a scam, a lie... SOMEBODY must have been happy back then with that quality of life!

In some ways, this film, which reunites "Titanic" stars Kate Winslet, Leonardo DiCaprio, and Kathy Bates, is reminiscent of "A Doll's House"-- a piece that challenges the conventional role of a wife in a more repressive era. Both  will end with the wife breaking out of her conventional role, and an environment in which they felt imprisoned, but in very different ways and for very different reasons.
 In either scenario, the husband will be left devastated. But whereas in Ibsen's 1879 play, there is some hope for redemption, in director Sam Mendes'(Winslet's then-husband) film, based on Richard Yates' 1961 best-seller, there will be a different outcome.
 Like Ibsen's play, this too, is a story of a mismatched couple who made many poor choices.
 Set in the late 1940s, then skipping ahead to the fateful summer of 1955, DiCaprio and Winslet play Frank and April Wheeler, who, amid the lovely music of the Ink Spots, meet and dance at a party-she an aspiring actress, and he a longshoreman about to take a job as a cashier.
 An edited scene depicting April's childhood gives some insight into her character. The book purportedly reveals her childhood to have been a troubled one, impacting her relationship with others as an adult.
 Our initial viewing of the Wheelers as a married couple in Connecticut is during April's less-than-stellar performance in a stage production of "The Petrified Forest". We hear audience members express relief when the play is over. A discouraged April sobs backstage as her friend, Millie Campbell (Kathryn Hahn) waits for her.
  Frank goes to the dressing room to see his wife afterwards. The first of many quarrels begins when they disagree about whether to rendezvous with friends afterwards. The row continues as they drive home, pulling over to the side of the road still bickering.
 Indeed, as many critics have said, this film depicts what many think would have happened if the fate of Jack and Rose of "Titanic" had been different.
 This film becomes a difficult one to watch as the couple with help from Kathy Bates' realtor, Mrs. Giving, move into a more desirable residence on 115 Revolutionary Road.
 Frank continues to commute to work with the Knox Machines firm in New York, and April, having abandoned her dreams of acting, tends the home, and their two children, Jennifer and Michael (Ryan and Ty Simpkins).
 Outwardly, their lives appear idyllic, but in reality, they will continue to be fraught with conflict. Frank reluctantly follows in his late father's  footsteps  as an employee of the same firm.
 On his thirtieth birthday, he has lunch with the young secretary, Maureen Grube(Zoe Kazan), which leads to an affair in her apartment.
 After Frank leaves, he goes home to his wife, who is apologetic about they way she has behaved since the play and his children, who have thrown a surprise party for him. The expression on his face shows him to be deeply moved, but the audience knows he is hiding a guilty secret.
  As they prepare for bed, April, recounting a time in their courtship when Frank talked about his time in Paris during World War II, and how he imagined finding fulfillment if he went back, recommends that  they move there, stating that  she could work as an government secretary while Frank studies and takes time to decide what he really wants to do, rather than stay in an unfulfilling job.
 Frank initially but reluctantly agrees to the  plan, but sharing the idea at the office as well as with Millie and her husband, Shep (David Harbour) seems to be to its detriment.
 Mrs. Givings,  frequently visits  the Wheelers, and at one point asks if her son, John( Michael Shannon), a Math Professor who has been institutionalized, hoping that some company might improve his condition.
 During a get-together, Mrs. Givings, John, and Mr. Givings(Richard Easton) discuss their impending move to Paris, as they previously had with Shep and Millie.
 But soon, April is pregnant again, and Frank is offered a raise at work.
 An outing at the beach with the Campbells provides a crucial moment in which Frank reveals that he is leaning towards staying in his position, much to April's disappointment leading to another quarrel. In the bathroom of their beach house, Frank discovers the equipment April had acquired to terminate her pregnancy, leading to another heated argument, during which Frank questions his wife's sanity.
  I would not call this  film a pleasant viewing session; the constant fights can leave one exhausted and demoralized.
  There is a notable scene where Frank  gives the definition of the word "inventory" while speaking into a dictaphone. It seems to set the stage for how he feels his family life should go as opposed to April's vision of what their life could be.
 His affair with Maureen continues briefly. Among the many noteworthy  entries of the film soundtrack is the song, "Crying in the Chapel", which suggests that the Wheelers might have fared better with some spiritual values.
  An evening out with the Campbells at a roadhouse finds Millie happy that the gang will stay together. While dancing with Frank, she reassures him that April will get over their not going to Paris. But a series of events finds April alone with Shep, who has been long desirous of her. After confiding to Shep her feelings of uselessness and of feeling trapped, they have a fling in Shep's car after Frank takes Millie home--despite April's pregnancy.
 Another dinner with the Givings leads to a brutally cathartic "sound and fury" moment with John, who though insane, proves he's no idiot, correctly guessing the couple's situation and the real reasons for it.
 After Frank's rage chases the Givings out of the house, he and April continue the feud  to the point where April runs out towards the woods, where the couple had had a more pleasant stroll with John not too long before, with Frank in pursuit. April warns Frank away. During the feud, Frank confessed his infidelity, to which April , who hadn't been sleeping with him for quite some time,is apathetic.
  Frank drinks himself to sleep, while April stays outside, smoking, only to find his wife in a better temper, cheerfully making breakfast the next morning, taking an interest in his job now that he has been promoted(inwardly conceding defeat) and giving her husband one last pleasant moment in her company, secretly harboring the fact that she has  made a fateful decision. She briefly speaks with Millie, who has been looking after her children due to her feeling unwell over the phone, tearfully tidies the house, putting the items Frank knocked off of her dresser during their latest fight back in order, and commits an irretrievably life-altering act....
 Upon the revelation of a tragic outcome, we find DiCaprio responding just as he did when he played another character named Frank( last name Abagnale) in another movie--running away from the site of misfortune with a pained expression, his head thrown back, and his 6-foot frame taking quite the blind, dramatic sprint down the road. Although the film differs from the book regarding the fate of the Wheeler's children, life will go on for their closest neighbors, although it will be sadder for both the men who knew April intimately, and Mr. Givings  will decide, as some justifiably will that the Wheeler's tragic story is one that should be tuned out.

As a person who would move to Paris in a heartbeat if my responsibilities disappeared, I could totally relate to April. April is a creative, colorful person who feels trapped in the rat race of life, in marriage, in motherhood, in the mundane. Frank, her husband in name, is feeling the dissatisfaction of the daily grind at working at a job who's company doesn't even remember his salesman father. April, not quite one to give up, devises a plan to get out of dodge, and Paris is a calling. The audience is somewhat surprised when Frank agrees to her fanciful and "whimsical" plan. (It was quite whimsical in the 50s. Nowadays everyone who feels the pull does it.) They put the house up for sale, and pack up most of their belongings. Then, Frank gets offered a promotion at work, and it seems to go downhill from there. All the old wounds get opened up. We see April struggle to hold on to "sanity". We see Frank struggle to hold on to April, his trophy wife. Ironically, Frank is the one who always wants to talk things out. April is the quiet, introverted type, who needs to just be, to think. Frank doesn't understand her need for space and resorts to hitting the bottle. Again, it's a downhill spiral from there. When April returns from thinking, it's morning and she asks how would Frank like his eggs. Anyone who can see the resignation and change in her, knows that no good will come from this interaction.

I was stupefied after watching this as this movie gave me pause for about an hour. What dreams am I burying to sustain my pace on the wheel? Where am I performing cognitive dissonance to survive? As a colorful woman, I could relate to April. But what about Frank? I could even relate to him in that as a man in the 50s, you don't rely on your wife to bring in the income. He possibly felt emasculated at the very suggestion, but didn't speak up then. However, his actions were very loud and clear when he accepted the promotion to possibly save face. He did not take April's feelings into consideration when he accepted.

The movie contained volatile scenes and was a bit jarring because I can't say that I've ever seen such raw passion and hatred performed on the big screen, or TV, before. However, these types of scenes is a regular everyday occurrence in some households. This movie was a real portrayal of real people.

I'm not sure why this wasn't more popular with critics - the story is good, the acting is very fine (by all)...I found the characters quite easy to relate to, esp. the wife (played by Kate Winslet).  I have a sneaky feeling people were looking for another Titanic-esque love story and this is definitely not one of those, plus the story naturally lends itself to the provocation of sympathy for just about every character in the film.  It wasn't overwhelming, though, at least not for me - I thought most of the characters handled the everyday disappointments in their lives (we all feel them!) pretty well, at least until the wife decides she can't do that anymore and things fall apart.  But that's pretty real, too.  I think as long as people approach this film as a whole entity unto itself (and do not lump it into some preconception of a sappy love story), they'll enjoy it very much.

I enjoyed the beginning of the movie. It showed a couple attracted to one another and each had a look to the future that seemed
possible. They got married,moved to th suburbs in Connecticut and appeared to have the perfect life and be a perfect family with 2 children. in the 1950's people could buy a home and car and all was perfect with the world. Then the realization came. It's not enough to have everything we always want more. They had struggles with communication. The wife had mental issues that were never treated and after a life changing trip to France fell through everything fell apart and became very troubling. It was difficult to see them go through these difficult times. If I knew what was going to happen in the end I probably wouldn't have watched it. Very sad. The acting was amazing.

I love Kate and Leo on this film.its about a young couple in the 50's in the suburbs. But Kate's character wants more.she doesn't want to be just an other ordinary couple like everyone else.as for her husband, he's just fine with it.

I watched this because of the lead actors.  Technically the movie was well made.  Good script, cinematography, acting, etc. But I had no sympathy for the characters.  April bombs in one play and she gives up on her dream. Way to go champ. That's what winners do;quit the first time things get tough. Frank has no guts or faith. So what if they went to Paris? They would have been fine. It might have brought out something great in them.  In any case, they weren't going to starve.  We're talking France not Uzbekistan. I suppose the author of the book that the movie was based on was trying to say something about the burbs and the salaryman lifestyle. I don't see it that way. This movie is about two jerks who created their own hell because of their cowardice and weakness.  No one has to live in the suburbs.  They're not gulags.  No one has to work in an office.  You have the freedom to walk out the door at any time.  They also had birth control back then.  They didn't have to have kids.  They screwed up their lives because of the choices they made not because their environment.

Thought is was deep in a subtle way. Dark but real. Kate Winslet is gifted in acting.  Would watch again, but for free :) .

"Revolutionary Road" is a movie I put off a very long time in watching.  I have to be in the right kind of mood to watch a movie of its kind--deep, thought provoking, and one that you and your friends can discuss into the wee hours of the morning.

Frank and April Wheeler (movingly portrayed by Leo DiCaprio and Kate Winslet, respectively) are the principle characters of the movie.  They are the embodiement of (at least on the surface) the American dream:  nice, beautiful house in Connecticut, children, picket fence, etc.  Trouble is, NOTHING is at it seems.  April is a women who lives--yet isn't ALIVE; Frank deeply desires his American dream to have it all, yet he cannot escape the nightmare that has become his life:  he is an adulterer, hates his job, and second guesses his manhood.  Their arguments build and build, until the bloodletting is almost as harsh as the characters of George and Martha in "Whose Afraid of Virginia Woolf?".

All this seems to change when April convinces him to LIVE his dream:  move to Paris (she'll work instead of him) and just let the chips fall where they may.  This decision seems to invigorate them both, and plans start being made.  That's when all hell breaks loose.

I am not going to give anymore of the plot away because if you get the chance, you really should see this movie.  The main actors were superbly cast, as are the minor ones.  Kathy Bates puts every ounce of gusto into her role as a real estate agent, who is trying desperately to find her mentally off-balance son a friend.  The movie is rated R (and this confuses me).  There is no violence, no nudity, a couple of sexual situations, and some language.  DiCaprio and Winslet are just unbelievable.  Although I'm not a huge DiCapril fan, I don't know what it would take for this guy to win an Academy Award.  Highly recommended.

This is nothing against the seller, everything they promised was correct.  However, the movie is horrible.  This was nothing like the short summary given.  And just a heads up, it deals with abortion and marriage affairs, so if this is not what you want to watch, don't buy it!

It was  flat;  great actors but characters unlikable so didn't really get into it.  I had read the book and wanted to see how it was transferred to the screen.  They did it by changing the plot, the ending.
Good movie!  I think Kate Winslet and Leonardo Di Caprio are great actors. The movie allows you to contemplate on how well you listen to your spouse.

i loved this twisted movie. i saw it on tv and decided to own it. first off- go to target or walmart and buy it for 3-6$ and for black friday even less. i got my movie damaged in the back , like the seller with a pen- crossed out the barcode and ripped the box!!! what the hell? 7$ for a damaged movie?? and of course its not even worth the hassle of printing and returning things to only wait several weeks for a refund?? great service.

I have watched this movie three times and I still find it mesmerizing.  The music is haunting and perfect.  The direction is brilliant.  The performances are all outstanding with special kudos to DiCaprio, Winslet, Bates and the ever-brilliant Michael Shannon.  For me, the movie depicts lives lived in quiet desperation with one chance to follow the road not taken.  They should have run down that road instead of walking in circles.  The characters are almost like Stepford couples but the acting is so brilliant that the humanity shows through.  Its amazing that people survived this time period at all.  If these were 'the ole days" I'll take the bad present any time.
The recipient of this gift was very happy. Would recommend for Christmas and Special Occasions. Order today for a wonderful experience.

Brilliant film. I'm now reading Richard Yates' astounding, richly layered novel with a friend. Considering the magnitude of the writing, I'm even more blown away by the deftness of the adaptation. Great books most often seem to suffer in translation to the screen, but not this one!
I have tried to play the DVD on different players and it will not play.  I have not seen the movie

Brilliant performances by Winslet and DiCaprio, in fact entire cast.  Great direction Sam Menzies.  Finally, a meaningful, profound story about marriage, suburban life, love, expectations and disappointments.  Everyone should be able to relate to this film.  Powerful, engrossing, and moving.

Great acting, good script but doesn't read as "real". First of all, where are the kids? We see the kids twice in the entire film and as anyone with a family and real middle class problems knows, kids put tremendous stress on a marriage. But not so in this film. The kids are never home, not even on a Sunday when they are having dinner with neighbors? That was just stupid. Omitting the stress of children was a mistake. And while I did like this movie and understood the emotions and frustrations of the characters, I find it extremely obnoxious when the super-rich, beautiful people of Hollywood who honestly do not have any idea what it is like to struggle and feel trapped by life, make movies about how trivial, pointless and unsatisfying life is for us "normal" people. It strikes me as extremely elitist, arrogant and down-right demeaning. I'm sure all of us middle-class "regular" people would love to know what it's like to make millions traveling around the world and getting paid to dress up and play make-believe in front of a camera, but since we don't, it's really a slap in the face to be told that our mundane lifestyles really aren't as worthwhile or meaningful as theirs.

The 1950's American dream....Family living in the suburbs, husband commuting into the city to work.  Wife at home tending to the children.  Family house with a white picket fence.  This movie shows all of this except that the family is not happy, both the husband and the wife are constantly fighting.
The movie shows that the American dream is not the lifestyle that everyone had envisioned for themselves.  This predetermined life has its downside and this particular portrayal of this family is struggling to breakout of this mold and try to live a life that is worth living.  Great story but sad at the end yet the message is clearly understood.

The trouble was that I didn't care about any of the characters at all.  The busybody wasn't bad, at least interesting.  But the rest of the cast, boring.  Wheeler, with his childlike face, didn't convince me at all.  Somehow the movies never get the 50s quite right.  The furniture is right but the mood is off.

I read the book by Richard Yates first, published in 1961 -- then saw the film. It's one of the best renderings of a work of literature I can think of. The director made it into a work of art on its own, while somehow managing to remain faithful to the original novel in depicting character and theme. And of course, now I can't think of April and Frank Wheeler as anyone else but Kate Winslet and Leonardo DiCapprio. They were perfect for portraying these complex characters. But I think I was mesmerized -- entranced -- most of all by the music, especially the haunting theme written by Thomas Newman. Cannot get it out of my head.
